On the Expertise note, it's good that they put it on a ring. You can't have it be an emblem item sadly, because then Hunters are stuck without an emblem ring (Sunmote anyone?). I'd rather have a ring slot to play with expertise cap with than have it be a deciding factor in juggling gear around for tier bonuses etc. Of course these stats are likely not finalized in any case.
Last edited by Chongar : 11/18/09 at 1:00 PM.
#273SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Gbits
I have an additional problem with our set once again being itemized (as all LK gear seems to be to date) for hunters-who-happen-to-melee: stamina. Yes, I know, stamina is the least sexy stat there is, but I'm tired of being 10k health behind some of our retadins (and 2k behind some of our mages). Rets are just an example; plate and leather melee as a whole tend to have more health - one assumes to compensate for PBAoE - itemized on their gear.

The early (placeholder?) stats once again put us almost 200 stam behind retadins, and that's just set pieces. It's not just plate; the rogue set, made for folks that have a few more get-out-of-jail-free cards than we do, has 100 stam more. Sure, we could gem for stamina, but our DPS is balanced around the maximum possible DPS-related stats being enchanted/gemmed into our gear. Honestly, I'm just finding it a little fatiguing to know that I'll be continuing to work twice as hard as my fellow melee to stay alive in most IC encounters, as I do now in ToGC.
#274SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Revdarian
Originally Posted by Andrast
This is completely untrue. There are 7 sockets on the 25-man tier set alone (not including offset). Socketing all of them with expertise gives exactly the 140 expertise rating non-orcs require.

I don't think it's optimal, and it's certainly boring, but it definitely seems like 7 of our sockets will be getting used on expertise gems.

Fakeedit: after rereading your post perhaps this is what you meant? It seemed not since you mentioned you were a blacksmith and profession has no bearing on the number of sockets you get on the tier set.
It does matter, since you have to at least use 1 of the 7 sockets for something other than expertise (Nightmare Tear), in order to achieve your meta socket.


EDIT TO ADD:

what you all seem to forget about the lack of expertise, is that such a thing takes away from freedom when testing stats... if most of your sockets have to be committed for expertise, you then can't test how would your dps be if you stacked AP, or Haste, or Hit, or heck ArP (if they were to add scaling to pets that they stated bluntly that they won't)

So yeah, there is an issue about the lack of expertise.
#275SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Silverstorm
Revdarian,

Something else to keep in mind is that because the gear doesn't have expertise, it will have all those other stats. Granted, I doubt there will be 4 pieces for each slot so we can play "pick 3 of 4" stats and test that way (by dropping one of haste, ArPen, AP, or crit on each of 4 pieces). Still, I'd hope that in 12 bosses we would have at least some choice.

That doesn't completely negate the lack of some expertise on tier gear, but it doesn't do much good to gloom and doom before we've at least seen the rest of the gear.
#276SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3crazyhammer
We are also losing 66 hit going from T9 Triumphant battlegear to equiv T10 gear. Not huge but tough to gem for that when you have all your gems slots stuffed with expertise.
#277SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
The thing to keep in mind is that the amounts of any stat get larger with every tier of gear and both expertise and hit are "cap"-able stats.

There is already a ring with 60 expertise on it, what if there is say a nice 2.6 speed axe with another 50. That would mean, as an Orc, I am already over the expertise cap with just those 2 pieces of gear and effectively wasting item budget.

Wait till all the gear is seen before complaining about the stat breakdown. If we are incapable of meeting the necessary caps then people can start complaining but we don't have enough information yet so just settle down for now.
#278SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Revdarian
I don't mean it as doom and gloom, just that i really like to feel some kind of freedom when choosing gear, and seemingly loosing that flexibility is annoying :-P

Also it is easier to just test stat stacking with regems than having to rely on raid drops, as i am sure that we all have found on the bad end of "random is random", so having higher flexibility on those = preferable IMHO.
#279SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
Originally Posted by Revdarian
I don't mean it as doom and gloom, just that i really like to feel some kind of freedom when choosing gear, and seemingly loosing that flexibility is annoying :-P

Also it is easier to just test stat stacking with regems than having to rely on raid drops, as i am sure that we all have found on the bad end of "random is random", so having higher flexibility on those = preferable IMHO.

If there was too much on the tier pieces you get just as locked out of loot as too little except then it would be even worse. What if they put 67 expertise on the gloves? Then as an orc I can't use that ring because it puts me way over the cap and the additional expertise would be wasted. With how they are now I can use my T9 gloves as an offset piece until I get that ring or another upgrade that has an equivalent amount of expertise and then upgrade my gloves to T10 without any real issues.

I'm actually more worried about the lack of hit on the tier pieces since we need a lot more of that to reach the spell hit cap, especially if we want to be capped without the 3% raid buff for 10 mans, but there is no need to fret about a loss of freedom until we see more of what will be available.
#280SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3davek
Originally Posted by Rouncer

Given that, between the Ashen Verdict, updated Dalaran Ring, and at least two rings so far in the instance itself, there will be lots of options to fill those slots it strikes me as rather limiting to point to the ring as an excuse to limit the flexibility of the other 3 races that need 140 points of Exp just so Orcs don't go over cap. Especially when Orcs could, just as easily, replace at least one piece of Exp toting tier gear with an off set piece to use the ring as well.

Additionally, the argument also runs on the assumption that the BiS weapon(s) for us in the instance won't be Maces, either because Black Bruise truly proves to be as bad as expected, they don't itemize an axe at the 262 lvl, or they do another 1 iLvL boost off of Arthas drops similar to Kel in Naxx.

Originally Posted by Levva
Yup extra testing with a hunter and viewing pet tab to see primary wolves stats would be useful. If you have ShockAndAwe installed it auto activates the pet tab, so you can see wolves stats & also view the more interesting info in the tooltips.
I have a Hunter and a Shaman on separate accounts, so I was able to use my own hunter to check this. Just using Beast Lore, I was able to view the damage range of my wolves via my Hunter.

Without using Kibler's Bits, I had a damage range of 471 to 596. With using Kibler's Bits, I had a damage range of 476 to 600. But there's one thing to note, it seems that you can only buff a single wolf with the pet food.
#285SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3davek
Looks like we've got a matched set of fists in ICC25; the aforementioned Black Bruise, and the recently found Keleseth's Seducer. Given that there's the Bloodvenom Blade to service DW Death Knights, it won't surprise me if that will likely be it baring potential end of instance weapons on Arthas.

If Bruise can't perform, we'll likely be fishing in the ICC10 pool.
#286SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
Originally Posted by davek
Looks like we've got a matched set of fists in ICC25; the aforementioned Black Bruise, and the recently found Keleseth's Seducer. Given that there's the Bloodvenom Blade to service DW Death Knights, it won't surprise me if that will likely be it baring potential end of instance weapons on Arthas.

If Bruise can't perform, we'll likely be fishing in the ICC10 pool.
Using EP values to attempt to quantify what we need the proc to be worth it would have to be worth ~175.33 dps to be equal to the 278.3EP stat value difference between the fist and that sword.

The proc says "your weapon hits" so lets work off the assumption that all weapon hits (not just mainhand hits) can proc it at the 1% rate. Over a 5 minute 4 second Jaraxxus-25H kill, I had 466 melee hits that should qualify under the conditions listed for the proc. That would be a hit every 0.65 seconds or approximately 1 proc every 65 seconds. Giving it an uptime of 10/65 or 15.4%. The melee component of my dps on that encounter worked out to 3565.8 dps so the 9% additional shadow damage would be 321 dps while active and with a 15.4% uptime that would be 49.4 dps.

If the proc's damage is affected by CoE and can crit separately then it would be worth 434.6 dps or 66.9 dps with the 15.4% uptime. Which pretty much matches Levva's conclusions from a page or so ago. So unless there is something we are missing that weapon is not going to be an upgrade when compared to either the 10 man ICC options or the current options from ToC.
#287SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Axaeron
I haven't seen a mention yet of "Shawl of Nerubian Silk." It drops of Marrowgar in 10man.

In its 10man normal (iLevel 251) version, it has 56 expertise, along with 41 hit, 122 attack power, 72 agi, and a red socket with a 4 agi bonus.

With the heroic version of this cloak (likely 60ish expertise), as well as the ring, you only need one expertise gem (unless you're taking advantage of your racial).

Since this comes from a fairly simple (from what I've read) boss in 10man heroic, it won't be hard to obtain once heroics are available.

Seems to me like there isn't any reason to be worried about our lack of expertise.
#288SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Neurosisxeno
Originally Posted by Axaeron
I haven't seen a mention yet of "Shawl of Nerubian Silk." It drops of Marrowgar in 10man.

In its 10man normal (iLevel 251) version, it has 56 expertise, along with 41 hit, 122 attack power, 72 agi, and a red socket with a 4 agi bonus.

With the heroic version of this cloak (likely 60ish expertise), as well as the ring, you only need one expertise gem (unless you're taking advantage of your racial).

Since this comes from a fairly simple (from what I've read) boss in 10man heroic, it won't be hard to obtain once heroics are available.

Seems to me like there isn't any reason to be worried about our lack of expertise.
With the way the gating is enabled you'll be looking at 3-4 months before you even have a shot at that item. That means that even if it has a miraculously high drop rate you'll be running short on Expertise or gemming for it for a very long time. I wouldn't exactly call an item we won't have access to for several months a solution to the problem. You also have to factor in the drop rate of the Ring and how many other classes may be chasing it down. The underlying issue is that they are treating Enhancement Shaman like Hunters, which won't work. We are a VERY different class that has VERY different stat requirements. I am really hoping for a change to the T10 stats before ICC goes live.
#289SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Mman
Originally Posted by Neurosisxeno
That means that even if it has a miraculously high drop rate you'll be running short on Expertise or gemming for it for a very long time.
Are you going to lose all the expertise on your current gear when you zone into IC? No, you will gradually lose it over that same period as you replace pieces of your current tier set. You will then be forced to gem expertise to make up for these losses until you eventually acquire the coveted gear with actual expertise on it. Sure, this is less than optimal, but I don't see a real problem with it either.

Weighted Averages for AoE/Single target in ToGC:

moved to: EnhSim updated thread
Last edited by pintor : 12/02/09 at 7:04 PM. Reason: moved post
#295SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Nevets_69
You say that you're taking a weighted average between the single target and multi-target fights. What sort of weights are you assigning to each fight?
#296SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3pintor
Originally Posted by Nevets_69
You say that you're taking a weighted average between the single target and multi-target fights. What sort of weights are you assigning to each fight?
Originally Posted by Nevets_69

Using a weighted average to work out the zone as a whole results in:
Average Duration 5:17 (317)
Boss+1 @ 124% (The higher percentage is to account for 4 adds on Anub)
Boss+2 @ 62% (this is equivalent, in case uptime cannot be >100%)

From your post in the EnhSim thread, I used the second option. 62% boss+2 adds, 38% single target. I simply simmed with 100% uptime for each fight, then used the % time you showed.

It may be better to break it down even further, i.e. assuming all 4 fights (I am excluding faction champions) last an equal amount of time (I know they don't): 36% single target, 45% boss+1 add, 19% boss+4 adds.
#297SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Nevets_69
Ah, no that should be fine. I just wasn't clear that is what you were doing.

The numbers I worked up (the 62% uptime for 2 adds) takes into account fight length for the 4 relevant fights in the zone. It's part of the reason that the number is so high, because the Anub'arak fight is so long (also because it has 4 adds).

Yeah, that makes much more sense now.


On that topic, I noticed that you used a fight length of 7 minutes with a RNG of 35%. The average fight length that I came up with for the zone was just over 5 minutes. Not sure how big a difference that will make.

When considering the RNG value, I know there has been a lot of discussion about it. I was kind of thought that if you just picked a middle (or median) fight length, and then adjusted the RNG so that the high end hits the longest fight and the low end hits the shortest fight (or something close; doesn't have to be exact).
That way, as the sim run fights of different lengths, it simulates fighting the various bosses in the zone in question each with their own duration.
Last edited by Nevets_69 : 12/02/09 at 6:24 PM. Reason: Added comments on fight length
#298SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3pintor
Originally Posted by Nevets_69
On that topic, I noticed that you used a fight length of 7 minutes with a RNG of 35%. The average fight length that I came up with for the zone was just over 5 minutes. Not sure how big a difference that will make.
I was going by our recent kills of bosses 1,2 and 4. We are still working on anub, but are getting to p3 at about 6:30, so I am going on the assumption our first kill will be ~9:00-9:30 in. I didn't want to push the RNG level too high and was also basing it on previous RNG discussion, so I settled on 35% and 7 mins, which let me go as low as 5 mins. Our fastest fight was twins, at 4:30.
#299SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Levva
Originally Posted by pintor
I was going by our recent kills of bosses 1,2 and 4. We are still working on anub, but are getting to p3 at about 6:30, so I am going on the assumption our first kill will be ~9:00-9:30 in. I didn't want to push the RNG level too high and was also basing it on previous RNG discussion, so I settled on 35% and 7 mins, which let me go as low as 5 mins. Our fastest fight was twins, at 4:30.
As it happens 7m and 35% are the new defaults in the config.txt file, arrived at by similar reasoning

#301SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Levva
Originally Posted by Shammiewow
Could someone please post some info on the new Fire Nova spell, and how that fits into our rotation as Enhancement Shammies? I haven't played on the PTR, and I'm unclear about what priority to give it in the rotation. And before anyone suggests it, I can't test it in Enhsim right now because Rawr can't download my profile.

The default setting of Enhsim seems to put Fire Nova fairly far down in the rotation, but I'm not sure how that would work given that Magma Totem is a fairly short duration. It's hard to imagine having two spare GCD slots close enough together to cast MT and then FN while MT is still up.
Entirely depends on whether you use 2 pts in Imp.Fire Nova to reduce CD to 6 seconds. Plus also remember that we are recommending moving MT towards the top of the priority list for higher uptimes and recommending using Fire Elemental.

#303SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Dahkeus
Originally Posted by Levva
Entirely depends on whether you use 2 pts in Imp.Fire Nova to reduce CD to 6 seconds. Plus also remember that we are recommending moving MT towards the top of the priority list for higher uptimes and recommending using Fire Elemental.
One other thing to consider has to do with fire ele totem and high movement fights. From what I understand, the fire nova effect comes from the fire elemental totem itself, which means that if you drop a fire ele on a high movement fight, you may not be able to fully take advantage of fire nova even if the fire elemental will continue chasing the target. Does this mean that replacing a magma totem and using fire nova is more viable or does the freeing of the gcd and increased damage of a fire elemental make up for this loss?

Of course, this probably has no simple answer since you may get some use of fire nova with a fire elemental before a boss moves out of range.

If nothing else, I think we'll have to be a bit more aware of when we drop a fire elemental totem and not just with regards to the cooldown.
#304SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
The 2 points in Imp Fire Nova don't really change much about Fire Nova's place in the priority list. It's real low in the priority list, just above refreshing Lightning Shield and below Lava Lash, for single target. Two targets it's just below Chain Lightning with 0/2 in Imp Fire Nova and just about even with Chain Lightning with 2/2 Imp FN. With three targets Fire Nova is above Chain Lightning when talented and about even when not. More then three targets and Fire Nova is better no matter how you are talented.

The talent is worth taking if you will be encountering any AoE at all so should be part of any raiding shaman's build meaning you hit Fire Nova if there is nothing else to hit when there is only one target and you hit it as often as you can if there is more then one target getting hit.
#305SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3reighnman
Can we get a list together of what needs to be confirmed, so that we can collect some data quickly once the realms come up. For example:

1. Rotation - Obviously where FE/MT/FN stand in the rotation, more data on FE vs. MT

2. Glyphs - Primarily FE - This glyph I believe was changed to 5 minutes? Still becomes useless if boss is moved out of range from initial placement?

3. Talents - Improved Fire Nova, where to pull points currently with 4p. set bonus (Imp Shields/Static Shock?) AOE best spec vs single target best spec, worth dual spec?
#306SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
Improved Shields, Reverberation and Ancestral Knowledge are the throw-away talents in any Enhancement Spec. From initial testing people will want 1/2 Imp SS and 1/1 Elemental Focus to maintain enough mana to use Fire Nova to full advantage even with using SR on cooldown. So that leaves 2 points floating in the tree.

Single Target with FN set to between LL and LS in priority list

2 points in Imp Shields = 40 dps
2 points in Reverb = 46 dps
2 points in Imp Fire Nova = 56

Add another target and the advantages to points in Imp FN are magnified exponentially. For anyone thinking about dropping points in Static Shock keep in mind that each point in SS is worth ~75 dps.
#307SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Levva

The second post in the EnhSim topic is where we are maintaining a list of things to check.

Originally Posted by Shammiewow
Thanks for your reply, Levva. And may I also just take this opportunity to thank you for all the great work that you do? The Enhancement community would be a very different place without your amazing contributions.

I saw that MT had been moved up the default Enhsim priority list, but I have not seen any info on the reasoning behind that change. Is that posted somewhere and I missed it?
We noted with more and more abilities in the priority queue that the uptime of Magma totem was dropping. Moving it up the list kept the uptime very high without losing much dps to GCD interference. It was a net gain to move it up the list.

Exactly what the new list of priorities should be is what I'm hoping someone spends a lot of time on over next week or so. I can't do this testing myself as updating ShockAndAwe + Rawr.Enhance + maintenance on EnhSim leaves little time to actually raid let alone test anything.

#316SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Mengus
25m vs 10m will be a factor when it comes to mana however. Personally, I don't raid 10m with replinishment, though there are several sources for 25m. Something to consider in how you lay out your talents.
#317SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3kurai01
Originally Posted by Levva
I read up on various posts and the consensus figure seemed to be 45 seconds. It would make a lot of sense to re-check this on the latest PTR as naturally a shorter GCD will make for a better uptime and thus a better enchant.

[Edit] I modified the Rawr source to suggest a 35 sec CD and berserking still came out ahead on my gear. Retrying with the BiS gear set from the BiS thread still gives Berserking ahead by a wide margin on either MH or OH. It looks like at current gear levels Black Magic is not at all viable.
Rawr continues to put Berserking ahead on either MH or OH by a decent margin, but EnhSim disagrees. BM comes out ahead of Berserking with a slim margin when enchanting the OH weapon.

I find this only true for the new 19/52/0 spec and FN low in the rotation. My older 20/51/0 spec put dual Berserking ahead.

This could simply be related to my gear, does anyone else see a similar effect? (I'm running haste>AP gems.)

#318SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Sprinter
After changing talents and glyphs this evening - i tested this in two different builds:
Gear: Mixed 245/258 // Glyphs: Feral Spirit, Stormstrike, Fire Nova
haste build: gemmed red: 20AP,10haste; yellow: 20 haste
AP build: gemmed red: 40 AP; yellow 20AP,10haste
Talents
The results were:
- Berserk in MH came always out 1st (BM/BM was NEVER superior)
- Berserk/Berserk or Berserk/BM was ~ equal
- Haste Build was ~40dps superior to AP build
#319SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Levva
Originally Posted by Sprinter
After changing talents and glyphs this evening - i tested this in two different builds:
Gear: Mixed 245/258 // Glyphs: Feral Spirit, Stormstrike, Fire Nova
haste build: gemmed red: 20AP,10haste; yellow: 20 haste
AP build: gemmed red: 40 AP; yellow 20AP,10haste
Talents
The results were:
- Berserk in MH came always out 1st (BM/BM was NEVER superior)
- Berserk/Berserk or Berserk/BM was ~ equal
- Haste Build was ~40dps superior to AP build
Why glyph Fire Nova? That is going to very heavily weight things towards haste I would imagine. Given that a 3 sec FN is going to screw the priorities royally. A 3 sec CD with a 1.5 sec (hasted less of course) GCD means that almost every second keypress FN would be available. This seems a BAD idea unless you are in very heavy AoE territory. On normal single targets you need the extra 3 sec to get in extra abilities.

Hint its a waste of a glyph if you are not actually making use of the extra 3 seconds CD. With all our other abilities I really don't see how you can make use of it unless you are almost spamming FN because of AoE trash. ie: Glyphing for an AoE build = ok, glyphing for a standard build I think is a mistake.

Originally Posted by kurai01
Rawr continues to put Berserking ahead on either MH or OH by a decent margin, but EnhSim disagrees. BM comes out ahead of Berserking with a slim margin when enchanting the OH weapon.

I find this only true for the new 19/52/0 spec and FN low in the rotation. My older 20/51/0 spec put dual Berserking ahead.

This could simply be related to my gear, does anyone else see a similar effect? (I'm running haste>AP gems.)

Can you give me some actual numbers please. ie: When you have berserking on OH and compare Rawr with Enhsim where if anywhere is the major variations. If you change to BM on OH and compare Rawr with Enhsim where are the variations. ie: look at each DPS component and tell me what component is giving the variation.

It could be that for instance Fire Elemental is being used in one and not the other or that the dps of Fire Nova is being calculated differently etc. What we need to test is with all the huge changes in EnhSim and Rawr where the actual differences are. ie: its not enough knowing the total differ. I need to know that for instance WF dps changed by 10 in Rawr but 100 in EnhSim when switching from Berserking to BM.

Oh and on the config. LL last?? Really? And cast_magma_only_if_ticks_left is recommended to be set to 2 to help uptime of magma totem.

#320SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3nxg
I was just checking on the comments to [Deathbringer's Will] , it seems that every class has a limited list of buffs they can get.
So for now we have to wait for someone to get it and confirm if it really only procs certain buffs for us and if so, which our buffs are.
In case it really works like that my guess would be we get AP, haste and crit.

Warriors seem to get ArP, Str and Crit,
Hunters AP, Agi, Crit,
Druids ArP, Str, Agi.

The internal cd doesn't seem to be 45s, though (most likely due to the 30s duration), seems to be on 90s internal cd.
So we need someone to confirm the cd, too.
#321SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Extenze
It's on a 2minute CD, regardless it's the best trinket. I'm more curious as to the buffs enh shams get.
#322SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		goropeza
In my 25 man ICC last night, I used only one point in Imp SS and my mana was fine. Seeing as all discussions are tailored towards 25 man raiding, I think we can confidently say it's not necessary for two points in mana regen talents. However, I was having issues with using so many GCDs before my priorities reset again. It's almost like LL is pushed out of our rotation altogether. With this in mind, I also don't think we should have any points in Reverberation at all and instead put them back into Imp Shields.

But anyhow, back to the LL issue, at this point with Fire Nova being put ahead of it in our priorities I think its safe to say the Totem of Quaking Earth is out of the picture entirely and ALL shamans should be using Totem of Electrifying Wind (until they get enough badges for the new SS totem). I will be more than happy to post numbers on these once I get the latest version of enhsim.
Last edited by goropeza : 12/09/09 at 1:49 PM.
#323SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
LL isn't pushed out of the rotation. FN is the lowest priority when there is only one target, it's really only worth pressing if you have 2/2 Imp FN in your build. Add more targets and FN goes up in priority but LL is still a good button to press.

Which completely conflicts with your totem selection since ToEW only procs when you use LB and if there is more then one target you want to use CL anyway and when there is only one target that is when you want to prioritize FN meaning LL barely gets pressed, etc. However ToQE has a 9 second cooldown anyway so reducing the frequency of hitting LL really isn't a bad thing in regards to that totem's uptime. With that in mind, I still recommend using ToQE over using ToEW.
#324SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		kurai01
Originally Posted by Levva

Can you give me some actual numbers please. ie: When you have berserking on OH and compare Rawr with Enhsim where if anywhere is the major variations. If you change to BM on OH and compare Rawr with Enhsim where are the variations. ie: look at each DPS component and tell me what component is giving the variation. The DPS improvement of putting BM on the OH is very slight, as Sprinter noted in his summary. (Typically under 5-10 DPS.) I've tried switching to AP gems, I've tried T10 gear with set bonuses, I've tried different trinkets, ect. In each case I see dual Berserking either equivalent or slightly lower than Berserking/BM from EnhSim. Rawr never shows BM catching up to Berserking in either hand.

It could be that for instance Fire Elemental is being used in one and not the other or that the dps of Fire Nova is being calculated differently etc. What we need to test is with all the huge changes in EnhSim and Rawr where the actual differences are. ie: its not enough knowing the total differ. I need to know that for instance WF dps changed by 10 in Rawr but 100 in EnhSim when switching from Berserking to BM.

Oh and on the config. LL last?? Really? And cast_magma_only_if_ticks_left is recommended to be set to 2 to help uptime of magma totem.

I'll include the numbers run with 10k hours simulation time below. The default EnhSim and Rawr priorities are different. Rawr has fewer options than EnhSim, but as EnhSim shares priorities with SAA, my play style will more closely resemble it than Rawr. I did not equalize their priorities by unchecking those missing in Rawr, but I did make sure that those that exist in both were sequentially similar.

As to the config, EDIT I see what ya mean Leeva, LS>LL>FN is superior to FN>LS>LL. Previously I was only juxtaposing LS and LL's priorities ignoring FN.

The cast_magma option set to 0 reliably results in overall higher DPS than 2. It is true that the uptime is a little better set to 2 ticks, but overall DPS takes a significant 65 DPS hit. My Berserking/BM comparisons above were done with a 0 MT tick setting, I'll add a run with 2 MT output being the only change. It appears that 2 ticks upsets the rotation enough that DPS is noticeably lower in LL and ES.

Data:
0 tick MT, Berserking MH, BM OH, LS>LL
EnhSim version 1.9.3.0

#325SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		goropeza
Originally Posted by Rouncer
LL isn't pushed out of the rotation. FN is the lowest priority when there is only one target, it's really only worth pressing if you have 2/2 Imp FN in your build. Add more targets and FN goes up in priority but LL is still a good button to press.

Which completely conflicts with your totem selection since ToEW only procs when you use LB and if there is more then one target you want to use CL anyway and when there is only one target that is when you want to prioritize FN meaning LL barely gets pressed, etc. However ToQE has a 9 second cooldown anyway so reducing the frequency of hitting LL really isn't a bad thing in regards to that totem's uptime. With that in mind, I still recommend using ToQE over using ToEW.
Here are the numbers I promised, the 1st is putting FN over LL with Totem of Electrifying Wind and the second is LL>FN with Totem of Quaking Earth.

Obviously if there are adds that make using CL more viable I'm sure ToQE will come out ahead, which is why it's probably best to have both of them. More importantly however, this shows that FN should indeed come before LL even in single target situations. In fact, FN>LL still comes out to be better even while ToQE is equipped. I would have included these numbers but I wanted to save the forum from an enormous wall of code. Curiously, FN is showing to be lower dps then LL yet the sim favors FN>LL.

Edit~When the totem is kept the same, both rotations win out depending on the test, hence there is no clear winner between priorities. Test your own gear with FN>LL with ToEW to be certain of dps increase for single target.

#326SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ryethe
Originally Posted by Extenze
It's on a 2minute CD, regardless it's the best trinket. I'm more curious as to the buffs enh shams get.
How do you figure? If what you're saying is true then: 30/120 = 25% uptime on Deathbringer's Will. From a guildy last night: 15/45 = 33% uptime on Whispering Fanged Skull.

Let's assume we're talking the ilvl 264 DBW and the ilvl 251 WFS. Let's also assume you proc the AP every single time on DBW.

DBW: 1200 AP * .25 ~= 300 static AP. 155 Arp ~= 155 * 1.5 ~= 232.5 AP.
WFS: 1100 AP *.33 ~= 366 static AP. 131 Crit ~= 131 * 1.9 ~= 248.9 AP.

I don't think its very clear at all that DBW is worth it for us. Especially when you consider the heroic WFS and the Herkmul War Totem.
#327SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3kurai01
Seeing Rouncer's post I now see what you mean about LL last. My previous rotation was FN>LS>LL. In that case, swapping LS and LL produced lower DPS. On the other hand, LS>LL>FN does produce better results. I'll edit my post above.
#328SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Rouncer
Originally Posted by goropeza
Here are the numbers I promised, the 1st is putting FN over LL with Totem of Electrifying Wind and the second is LL>FN with Totem of Quaking Earth.

Obviously if there are adds that make using CL more viable I'm sure ToQE will come out ahead, which is why it's probably best to have both of them. More importantly however, this shows that FN should indeed come before LL even in single target situations. In fact, FN>LL still comes out to be better even while ToQE is equipped. I would have included these numbers but I wanted to save the forum from an enormous wall of code. Curiously, FN is showing to be lower dps then LL yet the sim favors FN>LL.

Not "obviously" and it proves nothing except that people need to sim out their priorities based on their gear since LL over FN is "obviously" better in all my sim runs.

Besides in your other post you were talking about dropping LL completely which is ALWAYS a dps loss. Take notice of the Lava Lash ppms in both of your runs. One has you hitting LL on average every 8.29 seconds and the other every 7.98 seconds. Either of those maintains ToQE at a very nice uptime.

As for using ToEW instead of ToQE, that probably is a dps upgrade if the fight has no AoE at all. Moment there is AoE and you hit Chain Lightning instead of LB you were better off using ToQE, unless the AoE is so predictable and has enough of a pause that you can swap relics without the resetting of your swing timer or the GCD affecting your dps.


Edit - Besides wouldn't you want to test both sets of priorities with the same totem so that the totem couldn't be what is actually skewing your results anyway? More then likely all that your results prove is that ToEW is a slightly better option the ToQE provided you never cast Chain Lightning.
Last edited by Rouncer : 12/09/09 at 4:09 PM.
#329SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3goropeza
I never actually mentioned taking LL out of the rotation entirely. I simply said that I was using them noticeably less often. After looking more closely at the results it appears I was mistaken about the magnitude of this issue.

I also tested both rotations with ToQE and FN>LL still came out better. However, after testing it farther, it appears each rotation wins out depending on the test. So it appears to me that with each totem the same there's no clear winner between priorities. I will appropriately edit my previous post to reflect this discovery. However, the combination of FN>LL with ToEW still for me always comes out ahead of LL>FN with ToQE. You are quite right about how this only applies in a situational context. Universal truths are quite rare when it comes to Enhancement, so instead I would only like to point out the circumstantial difference between the two setups.

If in a single target situation, FN should only be used before LL if you have ToEW equipped. When tested without changing priorities the Totem only gives me around 4 dps, and changing the priorites WITH the totem gives me 17.
#330SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
This is what you posted.

Originally Posted by goropeza
But anyhow, back to the LL issue, at this point with Fire Nova being put ahead of it in our priorities I think its safe to say the Totem of Quaking Earth is out of the picture entirely and ALL shamans should be using Totem of Electrifying Wind
That statement is so wrong there is no argument or rationalization you can make that will adequately defend it. ToEW drops down to ~50% uptime in the sim when I added in 25% AoE time which really isn't very much when you think about it. Meaning ToEW is only better if you never have a reason to use Chain Lightning during an encounter.

What uptime percentage difference did you note when you dropped ToQE down a notch in the priority list? Guessing it really wasn't a significant difference though and that is because you are still using LL practically just as often in the sim even with the lower placement.

Let me try to break it down a little more for you. If there is any portion of an upcoming fight where using Chain Lightning instead of Lightning Bolt would be a dps increase then you should be using ToQE. So when fighting Patchwerk or a Heroic Targeting Dummy break out ToEW but for just about every other fight you should be using ToQE.
#331SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Telumehtar
Originally Posted by Levva
Hint its a waste of a glyph if you are not actually making use of the extra 3 seconds CD. With all our other abilities I really don't see how you can make use of it unless you are almost spamming FN because of AoE trash. ie: Glyphing for an AoE build = ok, glyphing for a standard build I think is a mistake.
Minor point, but if you know ahead of time that a given fight will be heavy on AE, carrying a stack of glyphs of each type and swapping them out as needed can gain you the advantage needed for either condition.

The question then becomes, How many mobs, for how much percentage of the fight make it worthwhile to swap out in favor of the FN glyph vs keeping a glyph focused for a "standard build". Depending on the nature of the fights in ICC (My raiding charter avoids spoilers as a rule so I don't know the details yet of each fight) this question may be worth asking.

Of course I don't know if someone would be determined enough to keep up with the cost of supplies and the cost to the pace of the raid in order to keep swapping glyphs or even specs(if we conclude differing specs excel under different conditions) as fights demand. But then you hear about people swapping entire trade skills within a week when it's advantageous enough to do so, so who knows.

#335SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3darkosmurph
Originally Posted by Rouncer
This is what you posted.

Let me try to break it down a little more for you. If there is any portion of an upcoming fight where using Chain Lightning instead of Lightning Bolt would be a dps increase then you should be using ToQE. So when fighting Patchwerk or a Heroic Targeting Dummy break out ToEW but for just about every other fight you should be using ToQE.
I'm sorry but I'm wondering just how often you use Chain Lightning? From looking at my meters, Lightning Bolt consistently puts out higher avg normal and critical damage than when Chain Lightning is hitting less than 3 targets. Due to range and other factors, I can't think of too many fights beyond Anub that benefit using Chain Lightning consistently.

With that said, I prefer Quaking Earth and find my DPS is generally always better when I use it.
#336SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
Twins, Jaraxxus, Beasts and Anub all have pretty heavy use of Chain Lightning in one phase or another and it doesn't need to be that heavy for it to affect ToEWs uptime considering it's cooldown and our frequency of MW stacks.

As for your meters you are reading them wrong. Each hit of Chain Lightning is counted as a separate cast in the meters. So your average damage is also including all the hops.

Looking at a Beasts we did recently my highest crit for LB (not including Ice Howl) was 11108 and my highest first hop for Chain Lightning was 10145. Highest second hop was 5255. 15400 > 11108.

#338SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3titansol20
Haste will only get you so far. AP should always win out. AP increases all your abilities, not just how fast you swing. As well as we don't sit and cast any spells, they should be instants either from MW5 procs or because their instants; anything else is a dps loss (unless your keeping your self alive or hexing something).

With ToQE, if you have the AP buff then use FN over LL every time... if not then LL over FN to get your AP buff to proc... Its the same for SS and ES, SS first to get the buff, then only use it to keep your debuff up.

The relative high mana cost of FN shouldn't be too overwhelming for raids in which replenishment is present, other wise your going OOM very fast even with the 6s Cd.
#339SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Levva
Originally Posted by titansol20
Haste will only get you so far. AP should always win out. AP increases all your abilities, not just how fast you swing. As well as we don't sit and cast any spells, they should be instants either from MW5 procs or because their instants; anything else is a dps loss (unless your keeping your self alive or hexing something).

With ToQE, if you have the AP buff then use FN over LL every time... if not then LL over FN to get your AP buff to proc... Its the same for SS and ES, SS first to get the buff, then only use it to keep your debuff up.

The relative high mana cost of FN shouldn't be too overwhelming for raids in which replenishment is present, other wise your going OOM very fast even with the 6s Cd.
That would suggest a partial priority that has LL_QE, FN, LL as part of the ordering, ie: if no QE buff then use LL over FN otherwise use FN over LL. That is nice and easy to test and as you say is similar to the other partial priority which is ES_SS, SS, ES!!

So perhaps our initial thoughts pre-patch of having LL_QE way up high in the rotation wasn't a good idea and perhaps having it fairly low and affecting FN is best. eg: something like...

SR, SW, SS_0, MW5_LB, FE, MT, FS, ES_SS, SS, ES, LL_QE, FN, LL, LS

That includes the two partial priorities as above.

#341SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Lumb
Originally Posted by PixitoBE
Are you saying that there is no point for stackin` Haste?
It's hard to say. Some shamans decide to stack haste, some go for pure AP and some go for a mixture between the two. Either way though, as it stands there doesn't seem to be much of a difference between either of those three options. If you're not sure a safe bet would be to gem for AP generally and then use the AP+Haste gems for yellow sockets.

However you're posting on a website which centers around minmaxing and getting the most out of your character, so you should probably use Rawr.Enhance / EnhSim and see for yourself. I'd put money on either of those telling you to gem for haste though.

#346SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ryethe
Originally Posted by PixitoBE
Are you saying that there is no point for stackin` Haste?
He's partially wrong. He's forgetting about the GCD lowering effect haste has on spells. Haste actually does more than just increase auto-attacks, it can potentially get us using more abilities per minute. It also increases MW proc rates. For me, I'm currently seeing haste stacking winning out for both single target DPS AND multi-target DPS. It seems this is because I'm casting more CLs, which is in turn overriding the damage lost on individual CL casts. Additionally, our rotation is very "full" right now so haste helps even that out as well as possibly getting us casting more abilities per minute. All of these things can increase our AoE DPS despite lowering the individual power each ability casted.

Shame though, was looking forward to running around as the various Northrend races.

#353SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer

I was talking about that with another shaman earlier. For what to buy first depends entirely on your current trinkets. If you are rocking a Comet's Trail AND a 258 Death's Choice then buy the Relic first. If your luck with trinkets is more like mine then save up the extra week (or two) and buy the Trinket first.

As for which relic to buy, I'm going with the Enhancement one but my reasons have more to do with quality of life then dps. Which one is more dps is something that is going to be debated for awhile in these forums since there really is no clear consensus yet on the Haste vs AP debate. Haste is definitely really good, it's more of a question of is it really that much better then AP in the actual game. I've just taken to following the advice of a friend and gemming everything with Stark gems till we get a real consensus on which is better.

Why the enh totem then? Because I do like to BG and I do run dailies too and I basically never cast Flame Shock outside of a raid but there aren't any circumstances in game where I won't be hitting Stormstrike. When there is nothing else to buy and emblems are just stacking up then I might pick up the Elemental Totem if it does end up being a dps increase over the enhancement one but I have a lot of things left to buy before I get to that point.

I happen to have [Comet's Trail], and I just recently picked up [Whispering Fanged Skull] from our 10man ICC.

I replaced [Blood of the Old God], as I was way over hit cap anyway, and the slightly less attack power for 50% longer duration was a no brainer for me.

I'm more interested in the comparison of [Comet's Trail] vs [Herkuml War Token].

Comet's Trail
Passive: 240AP
Proc: 726 haste for 10s (45s ICD) - averages 161 haste

Herkuml War Token
Passive: 153 haste
Stacking: 340AP

On a sustained fight, it looks like you get 100AP in exchange for ~10 haste, which seems worth it. I'm more curious about proc mechanics, and synchronization with other trinkets. [Comet's Trail] and [Whispering Fanged Skull] appear to have the similar proc mechanic (most damage dealt is a melee swing for us), so if they are consistently proc'ing together, I would expect that combination to yield higher DPS.

I guess mostly I'm looking for thoughts, since this is a much fuzzier decision than a lot of our gear choices, and I have trouble trusting the sim on this type of decision.

#363SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3bestpike
I was wondering how many mobs in an aoe situation are necessary to make double Flametongue better than WF/FT because of the extra spellpower while using Fire nova every 3 seconds. How would someone calculate that.
#364SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Mman
Flametongue provides an additional 211 spell damage. I believe the fire nova coefficient is 21.41%. This means that fire nova will be doing ~ an extra 45 damage. Under an ideal fire nova every 3 seconds this is 15 dps per mob. The magma totem has a coefficient of 10%, which means 21 damage every tick, or 10.5 dps per mob (ignoring the aoe cap, not sure what it is). The coefficient for the 2nd and 3rd jump total 68%, which would mean 143.5 damage every 6 seconds or an extra 24dps.

If you want to see how much of a dps loss not using WF is you could probably sim it. Create something like a 1 minute fight with a rotation similar to what you would do in an AOE fight. Sim it with WF and then with double flametongue.

The formual would then be: (WF DPS - (FT DPS + 24)) / (25.5) which would get you the number of additional mobs you would need to fight to make it worth it.

This obviously just an estimate as it ignores any proc/mechanics that favor single/multiple mobs.

edit: If you wanted to be even more accurate you could ignore my ideal dps figures and calculate what the dps would be from your sim log. For example, we know fire nova does an extra 45 damage with the extra flametongue weapon, but if you only managed to cast it 18 times instead of 20 in your 1 minute sim then the added dps is (45*18)/60 or 13.5. Same with chain lightning, but you can pretty much assume you will have magma totem up constantly.
Last edited by Mman : 12/11/09 at 6:25 PM.
#365SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3

#366SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3bestpike
I'm not very proficient with the Sim but here are my findings:

4 additional targets (+boss):

WF/FT = 10091 DPS
FT/FT = 9760 DPS

8 additonal targets (+boss):

WF/FT = 11130
FT/FT = 10839

At this point i realised the difference isnt gonna close anytime soon so i put 30 targets:

WF/FT = 16811
FT/FT = 16709

But if i remember correctly there is a new aoe cap in 3.3 that doesn't let you do more damage than equal with aoeing 10 mobs at a time, so i think its safe to say that FT/FT never becomes better than WF/FT due to that limitation. Levva maybe you want to limit the number of additional targets to 9 in future releases for some people could get confused.

#368SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Ryethe
Originally Posted by Morpheuspt
I have a question. What about we start accepting ArP as a "possible" stat in our gear? Since most of our gear in icecrown has armor penetration on it?

I know the loss is huge compared to haste, or attack power, but unfortunately we gotta play with the cards we're dealt, and blizzard didn't give us much of a choice in choosing haste instead of armor pen.

Thoughts?
What are you even saying? That we don't ignore gear with ArP on it? When have we ever ignored ArP gear? We used a bunch through ToC. I don't see how we can even have thoughts since we basically don't have a choice.

Don't get me wrong, ArP is suboptimal but if I'm offered a 264 with haste and a 277 with ArP, generally the ilvl jump is enough to make up for the suboptimal stat. Keep in mind that although ArP is bad, relative to other classes "worst stat" we come out pretty well. Go check out hunters and arms warriors with respect to haste if you ever want to see what a true bad stat looks like.

#371SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Cobs
Originally Posted by SentinelBorg
Fire Nova crits are also proccing Clearcasting.
Is it a 100% chance to proc on FN crits? Or is it a chance per mob? I ask because I seem to remember mage AoE having a modified chance to proc clearcasting on their AoE spells. If it's 100% then I would think EF is a far superior talent to the second imp SS as you'd have a very high clearcasting uptime in multi-mob situations which is when we need more mana efficiency (as FN gets bumped up in our priority so much.)

e: clarified a bit
#372SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
Originally Posted by Cobs
Is it a 100% chance to proc on FN crits? Or is it a chance per mob? I ask because I seem to remember mage AoE having a modified chance to proc clearcasting on their AoE spells. If it's 100% then I would think EF is a far superior talent to the second imp SS as you'd have a very high clearcasting uptime in multi-mob situations which is when we need more mana efficiency (as FN gets bumped up in our priority so much.)

e: clarified a bit
EF became a far superior talent the moment they fixed the bug with clearcasting not affecting the mana costs for Fire Nova.

Arthas is almost certainly going to drop a slow axe to go with the fast offhand axe. That was the case in TOC, and it'll probably be the case in ICC.
#374SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		davek
Originally Posted by Grulthak
Arthas is almost certainly going to drop a slow axe to go with the fast offhand axe. That was the case in TOC, and it'll probably be the case in ICC.
He doesn't need to. There's already a slow sword in Bloodvenom Blade to complete the required Sword/Axe spec requirements for Combat.

You're likely gonna have to hope for a Mace although, really, the answer here likely depends on how they intend to treat Arthas loot. If they go back to Naxx style 1 tier higher 'cause it's the last boss in the instance/expansion (and the iLvl on Shadowmourne may indicate this to a certain degree), then we can expect something for everyone to a point. If not, and they stick with the current hard mode/normal mode eating up the iLvL shift that Kel used to occupy, then really they can drop whatever they feel like there to fill holes and it becomes much more of a crapshoot as to what can be expected.

#375SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Levva
Originally Posted by Rouncer
EF became a far superior talent the moment they fixed the bug with clearcasting not affecting the mana costs for Fire Nova.
Can you post an issue on EnhSim as to what exactly EF should be doing now so that a rigorous test can be made to ensure its current with how it is in game. I'm thinking that perhaps Tukez put in something if there was a known bug.
#376SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
I posted a ticket about it already. How it was working on the PTR was Fire Nova would proc Clearcasting but then would not consume a charge and didn't receive the mana reduction. That is the model that is incorporated into EnhSim at the moment. At release they fixed that "bug" and now it procs clearcasting and can consume the charges as well as receives the mana reduction. It uses one charge per cast no matter how many things get hit and it procs off any crit no matter how many things Fire Nova hits.

The bug just refers to the behavior on the PTR. Prior to that there was no interaction between the talent and the spell as it was a totem so couldn't proc from a Fire Nova crit and couldn't consume the charges either.

Basically EF is a ~400 mana cost reduction on Fire Nova when active and it is active a lot when there is more then one thing being hit by Fire Nova.

#380SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Burka
It's seems I got a noob question here. Sorry for that.

We all know about EP and EnhSim is a great tool to calculate them. But may be it will be possible to automatically calculate the optimized Priority list by using these EP points?
Is it possible to make some kind of EP values for each spell(ability) in priority list which will based on main EP values?

For example if I got 2.37 Haste EP value in current gear- my SS_0 must be 1 and MW5_LB must be 1.5. (Just example)
#381SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
Originally Posted by 3Twilight
Just a simple question, if this is the rota to go:

rotation_priority1 SW
rotation_priority2 SR
rotation_priority3 SS_0
rotation_priority4 MT
rotation_priority5 MW5_LB
rotation_priority6 LL_QE
rotation_priority7 FS
rotation_priority8 ES_SS
rotation_priority9 SS
rotation_priority10 ES
rotation_priority11 FN
rotation_priority12 LS
rotation_priority13 LL


did i miss something? is fire shock > earthshock? why and when did it change?
FS is above ES because you are setting it so that it will only recast FS if there is 1 tick or less remaining on the DoT. If ES was above FS then FS would never cast. Also move LS up higher in the priority list but set it to that it will only refresh if there is 1 charge or less remaining. LL_QE has also been shown to be a dps loss and SS_0 doesn't change anything so they should probably be removed from your priority list.

Originally Posted by Burka
It's seems I got a noob question here. Sorry for that.

We all know about EP and EnhSim is a great tool to calculate them. But may be it will be possible to automatically calculate the optimized Priority list by using these EP points?
Is it possible to make some kind of EP values for each spell(ability) in priority list which will based on main EP values?

For example if I got 2.37 Haste EP value in current gear- my SS_0 must be 1 and MW5_LB must be 1.5. (Just example)
EP values don't work that way. They are just a way to compare the various stat values using AP as a baseline.
#382SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3AmbroTH
Originally Posted by Sprinter
(BM/BM was NEVER superior)
BM/BM does not stack and shares internal cd
#383SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3darkosmurph
Originally Posted by Rouncer
FS is above ES because you are setting it so that it will only recast FS if there is 1 tick or less remaining on the DoT. If ES was above FS then FS would never cast. Also move LS up higher in the priority list but set it to that it will only refresh if there is 1 charge or less remaining. LL_QE has also been shown to be a dps loss and SS_0 doesn't change anything so they should probably be removed from your priority list.



EP values don't work that way. They are just a way to compare the various stat values using AP as a baseline.
I think you're missing his question. He is basically asking, "When did enhance shamans ever start casting flame shock?" I'm a little curious as well. I cast flame shock but I also glyphed for it so I can get crits off the periodic damage. Without the glyph, does Flame Shock do more damage than ES_SS? Answering that would answer his question.

Also, can you clarify what you mean when you say LL_QE is a dps loss and SS_0 doesn't change anything? The guy posted his rotation. I'd assume getting your ToQE to proc, making all of your damage go up, as well as getting the Stormstrike buff on your target, would be beneficial and in fact "change" something over the course of a fight.
#384SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Saliik
Originally Posted by darkosmurph
I think you're missing his question. He is basically asking, "When did enhance shamans ever start casting flame shock?" I'm a little curious as well. I cast flame shock but I also glyphed for it so I can get crits off the periodic damage. Without the glyph, does Flame Shock do more damage than ES_SS? Answering that would answer his question.

Also, can you clarify what you mean when you say LL_QE is a dps loss and SS_0 doesn't change anything? The guy posted his rotation. I'd assume getting your ToQE to proc, making all of your damage go up, as well as getting the Stormstrike buff on your target, would be beneficial and in fact "change" something over the course of a fight.
Shamans started casting Flame Shock when it's duration got increased to 18 seconds. This was essentially a 50% boost to the damage per cast of Flame Shock, bringing it up above ES as long as you're not clipping the dot more than 1 tick.

LL_QE gives you a better uptime on the totem buff, but LL is enough weaker than other abilities, that you end up losing damage overall, even though you have slightly longer periods of time with the extra AP. SS_0 is the same idea, it buffs damage, but at the cost of using a weaker ability first. If you have a MW5 stack and hit SS to put up the debuff, you will possibly waste a few procs of MW, if you'd cast MW5_LB without the debuff, then hit SS, you'd get those procs toward your next stack, increasing your DPS, so they sorta cancel each other out.
#385SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
Originally Posted by darkosmurph
I think you're missing his question. He is basically asking, "When did enhance shamans ever start casting flame shock?" I'm a little curious as well. I cast flame shock but I also glyphed for it so I can get crits off the periodic damage. Without the glyph, does Flame Shock do more damage than ES_SS? Answering that would answer his question.

Also, can you clarify what you mean when you say LL_QE is a dps loss and SS_0 doesn't change anything? The guy posted his rotation. I'd assume getting your ToQE to proc, making all of your damage go up, as well as getting the Stormstrike buff on your target, would be beneficial and in fact "change" something over the course of a fight.
Guy above addressed Flame Shock so I'll skip that part.

LL_QE and SS_0 are attempts to quantify the benefit of having their respective buffs/debuffs active. Using them can increase your uptime of those buffs and it was very nice of the EnhSim coders to add them into the Sim. However just because they are there doesn't mean they are dps increases just as using ES_SS isn't necessarily a dps increase.

I've run many sims and found that SS_0 has no positive effect on my dps. Either it does nothing or it causes a reduction. That is not to say it won't someday be a dps boost, just that that day has not arrived. At least that is according to my testing, your results may vary so please feel free to test it for yourself and avail us of the results from your testing.

LL_QE ended up being a dps loss, plain and simple. That it would be a dps loss wasn't something that could be known until the sim allowed us to model it. Again your results may vary so please feel free to test it and if your results are different please post about them so the community can benefit from your labors.

As for your "assumptions", maybe you shouldn't try so hard. The simulator is what we use as napkin math doesn't do our "rotation" any justice and there is too much RNG involved in a single fight to allow for any meaningful results for comparison.
#386SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Deathicle
Originally Posted by Rouncer
As for your "assumptions", maybe you shouldn't try so hard. The simulator is what we use as napkin math doesn't do our "rotation" any justice and there is too much RNG involved in a single fight to allow for any meaningful results for comparison.
This is why I have questioned the need to have so many conditional priorities in our 'rotation'. As you yourself stated, the SS_O and LL_QE seem to add little to no benefit to the overall damage, and I highly doubt there will ever be a situation in which worrying about those instances in which you 'need' to cast those spells will actually result in a higher dps over simply using whatever ability is off cooldown at the time.

This is why I again advocate using a 'fixed' rotation, fixed in the sense that you do cast a MW_LB/CL, LS, MT et al whenever the situation warrants it, and let a simple macro worry about the rest. It was proven before that even the WORST rotation comes within ~1% of the maximum theoretical damage the simulator can do, and since no one here can walk on water in real life, you will never have the 'perfect' priority system in game. In many cases, simply having a 'good enough' system ends up being better in the long run.

And while it is highly amusing to see people with a 'new' priority system that increases our maximum theoretical dps by a whopping value of 1 - or less - in practice there are so many random factors that come into play in an actual raiding environment that such a strive for excellence does more harm than good. Whatever happened to KISS?
#387SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
Just because they don't add value now doesn't mean they won't and then you would be castrating the sim for no recognizable benefit.

I'm still an opponent of the "fixed" rotation because it makes for bad players. There are ranged attacks mixed in with melee attacks and if you just use a macro to handle them all then your macro could easily be locked up when forced out of melee range meaning you would then have to remember where you had another binding for the shock outside of that macro costing you dps. What if you need to use Frost Shock? If you are just spamming your macro how will you keep it reserved when you need to snare? Are you going to rewrite your macro just for that fight and then retrain muscle memory specifically for it?

I use macros a lot and if they would work just as well then I would advocate them. I castsequence macro SS and LL together (used to use a castrandom macro for them with an override for SS) since limiting LL to an 8 second cooldown was worth not having to think about it. Does it cost me dps? Probably but when I run the sim it shows a PPM for LL in an "ideal" rotation of 6.49 or once every 9.24 seconds. Maybe once per raid I find myself wanting to hit LL but my macro is on Stormstrike but that seems a small price to pay for convenience. However there is a big difference between that and sticking shocks into a macro with SS and LL and Fire Nova and spinning a mousewheel.
#388SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Deathicle
That is why you add reset functions into your macros. You could have a Wind Shear macroed with say, Frost Shock or Flame Shock, or pushing alt lets you reset your damage macro on a new target etc. That seems like it would be far less complicated than having to chose between one of TEN different abilities at any given moment, and actually lets you concentrate on some of the boss mechanics like knowing when to start moving just before Anub burrows, or seeing a Bone Spike 10 yards away and moving to kill it in Marrowgar, for instance.

Its a shame the simulator doesn't let you choose a completely fixed rotation. Fortunately, you are in the position to actually do a test in real game conditions and decide for yourself, or dare I ask if we have come to rely on the Simulator so much so that such testing is a waste of our time?

The shaman forums are filled with bad players with bad expectations, and rightfully so. The theory crafting discussion on these forums is far above the expectations that Blizzard has for its players as seen with the nit picking total rearrangement of the priority system for ultimately meaningless single digit or less dps gains. And then when players come here asking questions, or post on the wow Shaman forums and get a generic 'SIM IT' response they are overwhelmed with so many possibilities that it is ultimatly hard to nail down what exactly is important and what isn't these days, such as your LL_QE case.

So I propose this: we actually test a macro system and compare it to the priority system with a few key control cases IN GAME and actually see which one stacks up best or which one is simply 'good enough'.

Then, on TTT page, you can post a 'beginner macro' along with a 'new to enhancement shamans? USE THIS MACRO' explanation, and leave the 'priority system' up for those advanced players who wish to be bothered with such a complex decision making process.
Last edited by Deathicle : 12/15/09 at 6:47 PM.
#389SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Rouncer
No one is stopping you from doing the testing you are proposing. Go forth and test and return with your findings.

By the way, I use tons of alt/shift/ctrl macros. My Stormstrike/LL castsequence macro casts Wind Shear if I hold Alt and Chain Lightning if I hold shift for example. My Earth Shock becomes Flame Shock when I hold alt or shift (haven't found a good use for shift and that mouse button yet). Frost Shock becomes Hex with shift and when shift and ctrl are held it hexes my focus target.

There is a big difference between all that and a massive castsequence macro that just hits your abilities in some semblance of an ideal priority rotation which is what you seem to be proposing. What 10 abilities are you talking about anyway? There are 4 abilities you could castsequence together; SS, LL, FS and ES. Unless you going to stick Fire Nova in the sequence and watch it break when you don't have a fire totem active? Also Fire Nova is your highest priority when there are multiple targets but your lowest priority when there is only one target, so are you going to make two sequences? What if they glyph Fire Nova for a specific AoE heavy fight (like Anub), would that mean three separate castsequences?

Notice what I said about melee range and ranged attacks in the other post. Are you going to have people make a sequence with shocks and then bind another button for their shocks to use when they are out of range and their castsequence macro gets stuck on a melee attack or will you have them use a reset button to get back to Flame Shock and then refresh their Flame Shock unnecessarily because the macro is too dumb to know that it should hit Earth Shock instead? One way they have a dumb macro costing them damage, the other way they have to bind the shocks anyway but then they aren't good at hitting those buttons since the macro made them lazy. Unless you leave Flame Shock out of the macro but then that could be a nice chunk of lost damage. Although that would solve the issue of the macro Flame Shocking things that are going to die too quick for the DoT to tick out at least.

I like macros when they work well, just not when they only work well enough.

#393SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3pintor
Black Magic and Berserking uptime

It appears as though black magic may be increasing the ppm of berserking, possibly through an increase in white hits or windfury (thanks to Rouncer for noticing that).

Raid uptimes on berserking appear to increase from 40% to between 46% and 66% uptime on berserking with black magic on the offhand. The average increase I see is +13% (or 32.5% increased effect) across the data I have available to me.

I did some dummy testing and here is some results:

1. With BM on a 2.6 speed OH (with FT), and Berserk on MH (with WF): World of Logs - Real Time Raid Analysis
2. With no enchant on 2.0 speed 4.0 dps OH (with FT), and same MH: World of Logs - Real Time Raid Analysis

In case #1 berserking had a 39% uptime, while in case #2 it was only 29%. Additionally in case #1 WF procced 33 times, versus 19 without black magic.

Has anyone noticed a similar pattern?
#394SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Levva
Testing in game required of Berserking Main Hand - Black Magic Offhand

It has been noted that when OH is enchanted with Black Magic then the uptime of berserking in the main hand jumps in a very dramatic manner. We need users to test this in game and provide solid testing data of the effects.

[Edit: Pintor posted just before me ]

There is another report of this behaviour at Enhance: Black magic Vs Berserking? but unfortunately it lacks detail.

#396SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3
Edited onundefined		Rouncer
Originally Posted by Zensai
Maybe cuz I sim with 0 lag? Hmm it didn't save, let me recreate it. Here it is below, 0 lag, 0 variance, so that is why its higher then yours. Sorry about that. I'll resim my talents/glyphs with the lag and variance but I would expect I will still see the same results as far as which combination yielded highest DPS.
That would do it. Should always sim with at least 200ms of lag (I use 200-250 typically) since that is also attempting to account for human reaction time as well as server latency. Also should use the combat variance function as well, 35% is the currently accepted value.

Making those changes dropped your config down to 8942.71 dps.

Swapping Windfury glyph for Lightning Shield gains you another 30 dps.
Swapping a point in reverb for a point in Elemental Focus gets you another 20 dps.
Dropping LS refresh to 1 charge remaining and then moving it's priority to above MW5-LB gained 87 dps

Dropping that last point in reverb and putting a point in Imp SS will gain you about 1.5 dps for a single target encounter.
Dropping that last point in reverb and adding 1 point in Imp SS will gain you 20 dps when there are 2 additional targets 35% of the time and Fire Nova is moved to just under MW5 in the priority list (swapping to chain lightning during the multi-target phases).

Dropping SS_0 from the priority list costs 3.33 dps so looks like it is worth keeping there after all.

Overall Gain - 140.89 dps

So this is the spec/glyphs with the highest dps for your gear Talent Calculator - World of Warcraft
using this priority config SW, SR, SS_0, LS, MW5_LB, MT, FS, ES_SS, SS, ES, LL, FN with LS set to refresh at 1 charge, MT at 2 ticks and FS at 0 ticks.

#397SourcePosted onPatch 2.4.3Levva
Originally Posted by pintor
1. With BM on a 2.6 speed OH (with FT), and Berserk on MH (with WF): World of Logs - Real Time Raid Analysis
2. With no enchant on 2.0 speed 4.0 dps OH (with FT), and same MH: World of Logs - Real Time Raid Analysis
In your two logs with BM (2.6 speed weapon) you have

Melee : 1.087 Aps, Windfury : 0.204 Aps, Flametongue : 0.508 Aps (Aps = attacks per second)

for no BM (2.0 speed weapon) you have

Melee : 1.246 Aps, Windfury : 0.126 Aps, Flametongue : 0.651 Aps.

Now you'd expect an uplift in Aps with a faster weapon. However its windfury that very significantly bucks this trend.

I think we need tests with two identical speed weapons as that is a major variable.

I don't mind helping out with dropping some gold on enchanting a green weapon or whatever, but I want to make sure that the information produced is useful.

for no BM (2.0 speed weapon) you have

Melee : 1.246 Aps, Windfury : 0.126 Aps, Flametongue : 0.651 Aps.

Now you'd expect an uplift in Aps with a faster weapon. However its windfury that very significantly bucks this trend.
